<lb/>correction of the quarto’s page numbering. There are many oddities of signatures<lb/>and paper in this sequence in the quarto but it is noteworthy that all the poems<lb/>except <hi rend="italic">To a Lady</hi> begin with a single leaf. The reason must be that the numbers<lb/>of the epistles on the dropped heads (‘<hi rend="smallcaps">EPISTLE I</hi>’ etc. as in figure 8) had to be<lb/>changed, and that was done by supplying a new leaf.<hi rend="sup">42</hi> The present first page of<lb/>quarto <hi rend="italic">To Cobham</hi>, therefore, was printed at a late stage, but before the type was<lb/>rearranged for the folio. The page lacks line numbers on both recto and verso<lb/>and it has two readings corrected in the Errata: line 9 ‘the fate of all Extremes<lb/>are such’ and line 14 ‘those from Guess’. The large paper folio catches and cor­<lb/>rects the first but not the second of these. The quarto page must then have been<lb/>printed just too early to catch the revised headpiece. If it had not been printed<lb/>quite so hastily, we might never have seen the adapted <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> ornament.<lb/><lb/>The adapted headpiece in the quarto <hi rend="italic">To Cobham</hi> (figure 8) comes from <hi rend="italic">Odys­<lb/>sey</hi> Book V. Savage is surely right in suggesting that Kent’s original decision to<lb/>represent Calypso’s cave as a grotto was intended as a tribute to Pope; his own<lb/>sketches of Pope and his grotto are celebrated.<hi rend="sup">43</hi> The central circle in which<lb/>Ulysses was building his ship has been replaced by a simplified version of Cob­<lb/>ham’s arms, though Mercury, flying to bring Jupiter’s message, is still visible to<lb/>the left. The replacement engraving (figure 9), which does bear Kent’s initials,<lb/>is more straightforwardly heraldic. Whereas in the adapted engraving the shield<lb/>has only one eagle displayed, the new one has quartered arms with the eagles<lb/>displayed in the first and fourth quarter. Although it is not altogether clear, the<lb/>second and third quarters have two bars each, charged with three martlets. Sir<lb/>Bernard Burke says these are the arms of the kingdom of Mercia, borne by the<lb/>family since the Temples were earls of Mercia.<hi rend="sup">44</hi> But although the shield is heral­<lb/>dically correct, the supporters are not. The lions rampant on the adapted <hi rend="italic">Odyssey<lb/></hi>headpiece have been replaced by the putti of the ‘UNI ÆQVVS VIRTVTI ATQ.<lb/>EIVS AMICI’ ornament. Temple’s aristocratic dignity is playfully surrounded by<lb/>symbols of friendship.<lb/><lb/>The putti will reappear as supporters on the ornament that concludes <hi rend="italic">To<lb/>Oxford</hi>, but the next two poems, <hi rend="italic">To a Lady</hi> and <hi rend="italic">To Bathurst</hi> lack heraldic orna­<lb/>ments, though <hi rend="italic">To a Lady</hi> concludes with the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> fountain engraving. I have no<lb/>explanation for the non-appearance of Bathurst’s arms. His poem has no engrav­<lb/>ings, and neither does <hi rend="italic">To Burlington</hi> in the quarto, but in the large-paper folio <hi rend="italic">To<lb/>Burlington</hi> concludes with an ornament that was obviously designed by Kent (who<lb/>initials it) as a headpiece (figure 10). The Greek key molding that provides a plat­<lb/>form for the design is characteristic of many of the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> headpieces, including<lb/>figure 6, as is the firm oblong shape of the plate, occupying the width of the page.<lb/>I think Pope uses this headpiece (and the one for <hi rend="italic">To Oxford</hi>) as a tailpiece in order<lb/><lb/><hi rend="sup">42.</hi> Possibly the ‘Taste’ poems were originally to precede the ‘Characters’ ones (though the<lb/>‘Opus Magnum’ list, published by mistake in some copies of <hi rend="italic">An Essay on Man</hi> on 2 May 1734,<lb/>has the present order). <hi rend="italic">To a Lady</hi> was not published until 8 February 1735 and so its printing in<lb/>the <hi rend="italic">Works</hi> could be run on from <hi rend="italic">To Cobham</hi> with the appropriate number.<lb/><hi rend="sup">43.</hi> Nos. 14–16 in W. K. Wimsatt, <hi rend="italic">The Portraits of Alexander Pope</hi>, 119–25.<lb/><hi rend="sup">44.</hi> <hi rend="italic">The General Armory of England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales</hi> (London: Harrison, 1884), s.n.<lb/>The arms were illustrated in Guillim, <hi rend="italic">A Display of Heraldry</hi>, after p. 2120, no. 11.<lb/>
